sen.j: 三浦 義村（みうら よしむら）は、鎌倉時代初期の相模国の武将。
sen.e: Yoshimura MIURA was a general in the beginning of the Kamakura era. He was an influential busho (Japanese military commander) of the Sagami Province.
Yoshimura MIURA was a busho (Japanese military commander) of the Sagami Province in the beginning of the Kamakura Period.
sen.cmt: 二文を一文にしました。
sen.e: Yoshimura MIURA was a busho (Japanese military commander) of the Sagami Province in the beginning of the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の有力御家人。
sen.e: He was a powerful senior vassal in the Kamakura bakufu.
He was a powerful senior vassal in the Kamakura bakufu.
He was a powerful senior vassal in the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 本姓は平氏。
sen.e: His original last name was Taira.
His original last name was Taira.
His original last name was Taira.

sen.j: 家系は桓武平氏の流れで平良文を祖とする坂東八平氏のひとつ三浦氏。
sen.e: His bloodline can be traced back to Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan), and he was of the Banto-Eight Heishi, which stems from TAIRA no Yoshifumi.
His bloodline can be traced back to Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan), and he was of the Banto-Eight Heishi, which stems from TAIRA no Yoshifumi.
His bloodline can be traced back to Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan), and he was of the Banto-Eight Heishi, which stems from TAIRA no Yoshifumi.

sen.j: 三浦義澄の次男。
sen.e: He was the second son of Yoshizumi MIURA
He was the second son of Yoshizumi MIURA
He was the second son of Yoshizumi MIURA

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）、源頼朝の挙兵に父・義澄とともに参加する。
sen.e: In 1180, he joined MINAMOTO no Yoritomo's army with his father, Yoshizumi.
In 1180, he joined MINAMOTO no Yoritomo's army with his father, Yoshizumi.
In 1180, he joined MINAMOTO no Yoritomo's army with his father, Yoshizumi.

sen.j: 三浦氏は代々源氏に仕え、平氏打倒に大きな役割を果たしており、一大勢力として鎌倉幕府で重要な地位を占めていた。
sen.e: For generations, the MIURA clan served the MINAMOTO clan, and played a major role in the defeat of the TAIRA clan; as a major powerhouse, they held significant influence in the Kamakura bakufu.
For generations, the MIURA clan served the MINAMOTO clan, and played a major role in the defeat of the TAIRA clan; as a major powerhouse, they held significant influence in the Kamakura bakufu.
For generations, the MIURA clan served the MINAMOTO clan, and played a major role in the defeat of the TAIRA clan; as a major powerhouse, they held significant influence in the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 建久元年（1190年）に右兵衛尉に任官される。
sen.e: In 1190, the clan was appointed as a lieutenant in Uhyo-e.
In 1190, the clan was appointed as a lieutenant in Uhyo-e.
In 1190, the clan was appointed as a lieutenant in Uhyo-e.

sen.j: 正治元年（1199年）の梶原景時の変では中心的役割を果たし、元久2年 （1205年）の畠山重忠の乱にも参加。
sen.e: In 1199, during the incident of Kagetoki KAJIWARA, he played a major role, and also participated in the incident of Shigetada HATAKEYAMA.
In 1199, during the incident of Kagetoki KAJIWARA, he played a major role, and also participated in the incident of Shigetada HATAKEYAMA.
In 1199, during the incident of Kagetoki KAJIWARA, he played a major role, and also participated in the incident of Shigetada HATAKEYAMA.

sen.j: 建暦3年（1213年）には従兄弟で侍所所司であった和田義盛と北条氏打倒で結ぶが、これを直前で裏切って北条義時に義盛の挙兵を告げ、義盛は敗れて和田氏は滅ぶ（和田合戦）。
sen.e: In 1213, he formed an alliance with his cousin Yoshimori WADA, the Samurai-dokoro shoshi at the time, in order to defeat the Hojo clan, but he betrayed Yoshimori at the last minute by informing Yoshitoki HOJO that Yoshimori has raised an army; consequently, Yoshimori was defeated, and the WADA clan was destroyed.

In 1213, he formed an alliance with his cousin Yoshimori WADA, the Samurai-dokoro shoshi at the time, in order to defeat the Hojo clan, but he betrayed Yoshimori at the last minute by informing Yoshitoki HOJO that Yoshimori has raised an army; consequently, Yoshimori was defeated, and the WADA clan was destroyed (Battle of WADA).

In 1213, he formed an alliance with his cousin Yoshimori WADA, the Samurai-dokoro shoshi at the time, in order to defeat the Hojo clan, but he betrayed Yoshimori at the last minute by informing Yoshitoki HOJO that Yoshimori has raised an army; consequently, Yoshimori was defeated, and the WADA clan was destroyed (Battle of WADA).

sen.j: 大きな策謀には関わっており、幕政での地位を向上させることに腐心している。
sen.e: He was involved in many major conspiracies, and was keenly interested in making his way up the political ladder in the shogunate.
He was involved in many major conspiracies, and was keenly interested in making his way up the political ladder in the shogunate.
He was involved in many major conspiracies, and was keenly interested in making his way up the political ladder in the shogunate.

sen.j: 建保6年（1218年）、侍所所司に就任した。
sen.e: In 1218, he was appointed as one of the directors of police department.
In 1218, he was appointed as one of the directors of police department.
In 1218, he was appointed as one of the directors of police department.

sen.j: 建保7年（1219年）1月27日 (旧暦)、3代将軍源実朝が公暁（源頼家の子）に暗殺される。
sen.e: On January 17th, 1219, the 3rd generation shogun MINAMOTO no Sanetomo was assassinated by Kugyo (MINAMOTO no Yoriie's son).
On January 17th, 1219, the 3rd generation shogun MINAMOTO no Sanetomo was assassinated by Kugyo (MINAMOTO no Yoriie's son).
On January 17th, 1219, the 3rd generation shogun MINAMOTO no Sanetomo was assassinated by Kugyo (MINAMOTO no Yoriie's son).

sen.j: 公暁は義村に対し「我こそは東国の大将軍である。
sen.e: Kugyo sent a message to Yoshimura, saying, "I am the new Daishogun (commander-in-chief) of Togoku (Eastern provinces)."
Kugyo sent a message to Yoshimura, saying, "I am the new Daishogun (commander-in-chief) of Togoku (Eastern provinces)."
Kugyo sent a message to Yoshimura, saying, "I am the new Daishogun (commander-in-chief) of Togoku (Eastern provinces)."

sen.j: その準備をせよ」という書状を持った使いを出し、義村は「お迎えの使者を差し上げます」と偽って討手を差し向けた。
sen.e: "Prepare for my arrival." To this, Yoshimura lied, saying "We will send you an envoy once the preparation has been made," and sent an assassin after him.
"Prepare for my arrival." To this, Yoshimura lied, saying "We will send you an envoy once the preparation has been made," and sent an assassin after him.
"Prepare for my arrival." To this, Yoshimura lied, saying "We will send you an envoy once the preparation has been made," and sent an assassin after him.

sen.j: 待ちきれなくなった公暁が義村宅に行こうと裏山に登ったところで討手に遭遇し、激しく戦って振り払い、義村宅の塀を乗り越えようとした所を殺害された。
sen.e: Kugyo eventually lost his patience, and made his way up the back mountain to Yoshimura's home, where he encountered the assassin; after a fierce battle, he shook of the assassin, but was killed while climbing the wall surrounding Yoshimura's home.

Kugyo eventually lost his patience, and made his way up the back mountain to Yoshimura's home, where he encountered the assassin; after a fierce battle, he shook of the assassin, but was killed while climbing the wall surrounding Yoshimura's home.

Kugyo eventually lost his patience, and made his way up the back mountain to Yoshimura's home, where he encountered the assassin; after a fierce battle, he shook of the assassin, but was killed while climbing the wall surrounding Yoshimura's home.

sen.j: この事件の真相は明らかではないが、公暁の乳母は義村の妻であり、子の三浦光村は公暁の門弟であるなど、義村との縁が深い事から、事件は公暁をそそのかして実朝と義時を同時に葬ろうとした義村が黒幕であるとする見方もある。
sen.e: The details of this incident are lost, but there is a theory that Yoshimura was the mastermind behind it all, who provoked Kugyo into assassinating Sanemoto, in order to be rid of those two at the same time; Yoshimura's wife was Kugyo's wet nurse, and his son was a disciple in the Kugyo household, suggesting that Yoshimura had close ties with Kugyo, which makes this theory plausible.

The details of this incident are lost, but there is a theory that Yoshimura was the mastermind behind it all, who provoked Kugyo into assassinating Sanemoto, in order to be rid of those two at the same time; Yoshimura's wife was Kugyo's wet nurse, and his son, Mitsumura MIURA, was a disciple in the Kugyo household, suggesting that Yoshimura had close ties with Kugyo, which makes this theory plausible.

The details of this incident are lost, but there is a theory that Yoshimura was the mastermind behind it all, who provoked Kugyo into assassinating Sanemoto, in order to be rid of those two at the same time; Yoshimura's wife was Kugyo's wet nurse, and his son, Mitsumura MIURA, was a disciple in the Kugyo household, suggesting that Yoshimura had close ties with Kugyo, which makes this theory plausible.

sen.j: 公暁討伐の功により、同年駿河国守に任官。
sen.e: Due to his achievement in subduing Kugyo's usurpation, he was appointed as local director of Suruga region within the same year.
Due to his achievement in subduing Kugyo's usurpation, he was appointed as local director of Suruga region within the same year.
Due to his achievement in subduing Kugyo's usurpation, he was appointed as local director of Suruga region within the same year.

sen.j: 承久3年（1221年）の承久の乱では、後鳥羽天皇の近臣だった弟の三浦胤義から決起をうながす使者を送られるが、義村は直ちにこれを義時に知らせた。
sen.e: In 1221's Jokyu War, he received word from his brother, Taneyoshi MIURA, who was a close advisor of the Emperor Gotoba, urging him to rise and take action; Yoshimura immediately notified Yoshitoki of this.

In 1221's Jokyu War, he received word from his brother, Taneyoshi MIURA, who was a close advisor of the Emperor Gotoba, urging him to rise and take action; Yoshimura immediately notified Yoshitoki of this.

In 1221's Jokyu War, he received word from his brother, Taneyoshi MIURA, who was a close advisor of the Emperor Gotoba, urging him to rise and take action; Yoshimura immediately notified Yoshitoki of this.

sen.j: 義村は幕府軍の大将の一人として東海道をのぼり、京方を破って上洛。
sen.e: Yoshimura make his way up the Tokai-do Road as one of the bakfu army's Daisho (Major Captain), and returned to the capital after defeating the kyogata (supporters of the Imperial court in Kyoto).
Yoshimura make his way up the Tokai-do Road as one of the bakfu army's Daisho (Major Captain), and returned to the capital after defeating the kyogata (supporters of the Imperial court in Kyoto).
Yoshimura make his way up the Tokai-do Road as one of the bakfu army's Daisho (Major Captain), and returned to the capital after defeating the kyogata (supporters of the Imperial court in Kyoto).

sen.j: 胤義は敗死した。
sen.e: Taneyoshi was defeated and killed.
Taneyoshi was defeated and killed.

sen.j: 元仁元年（1224年）、北条義時が病死すると、後家の伊賀の方が自分の実子である北条政村を執権に、娘婿の一条実雅を将軍に立てようとした伊賀氏の変が起こる。
sen.e: After the death of Yoshitoki HOJO in 1224, his widow, Iga no kata, aspired to make her son, Masamura HOJO, the shikken (close advisor to the shogun and the second highest position in bakufu), and her son-in-law, Sanemasa ICHIJO, the Shogun, and caused an incident known as the Igashi no hen.

After the death of Yoshitoki HOJO in 1224, his widow, Iga no kata, aspired to make her son, Masamura HOJO, the shikken (close advisor to the shogun and the second highest position in bakufu), and her son-in-law, Sanemasa ICHIJO, the Shogun, and caused an incident known as the Igashi no hen.

After the death of Yoshitoki HOJO in 1224, his widow, Iga no kata, aspired to make her son, Masamura HOJO, the shikken (close advisor to the shogun and the second highest position in bakufu), and her son-in-law, Sanemasa ICHIJO, the Shogun, and caused an incident known as the Igashi no hen.

sen.j: 政村の烏帽子親であった義村はこの陰謀に関わるが、尼将軍北条政子が単身で義村宅に説得に赴いた事により翻意し、事件は伊賀の方一族の追放のみで収拾した。
sen.e: Yoshimura, who was eboshi-oya (a person who puts an eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) on a young man's head on his genpuku ceremony) to Masamura, was also involved in this ploy, but the ama shogun (nun warlord) Masako HOJO personally paid a visit to Yoshimura's home, convincing him otherwise; the incident ended with the banishment of the Iga family.

Yoshimura, who was eboshi-oya (a person who puts an eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) on a young man's head on his genpuku ceremony) to Masamura, was also involved in this ploy, but the ama shogun (nun warlord) Masako HOJO personally paid a visit to Yoshimura's home, convincing him otherwise; the incident ended with the banishment of the Iga family.

Yoshimura, who was eboshi-oya (a person who puts an eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) on a young man's head on his genpuku ceremony) to Masamura, was also involved in this ploy, but the ama shogun (nun warlord) Masako HOJO personally paid a visit to Yoshimura's home, convincing him otherwise; the incident ended with the banishment of the Iga family.

sen.j: 嘉禄元年（1225年）、評定衆が設置されると、義村はこれに就任した。
sen.e: When the hyojoshu (Council of State) was established in 1225, Yoshimura became a member.
When the hyojoshu (Council of State) was established in 1225, Yoshimura became a member of this.
When the hyojoshu (Council of State) was established in 1225, Yoshimura became a member of this.

sen.j: 御成敗式目の制定にも署名した。
sen.e: He also signed the Goseibai-shikimoku (the samurai code of conduct).
He also signed the Goseibai-shikimoku (the samurai code of conduct).
He also signed the Goseibai-shikimoku (the samurai code of conduct).

sen.j: 延応元年12月5日（1245年12月31日）死去。
sen.e: He died on December 31, 1245.
He died on December 31, 1245.
He died on December 31, 1245.

sen.j: 義村は京都の貴族の間にさえ「六権八略」の権謀家として知られていた。
sen.e: He was known among the Kyoto aristocrats as an ambitious political schemer.
He was known among the Kyoto aristocrats as an ambitious political schemer.
He was known among the Kyoto aristocrats as an ambitious political schemer.

sen.j: 『古今著聞集』には、将軍御所の侍の間の上座を占めていた義村のさらに上座に、若い下総国の豪族千葉胤綱が着座し、不快に思った義村が「下総の犬めは寝場所を知らぬな」とつぶやくと、胤綱は「三浦の犬は友を食らうぞ」と切り返し、和田合戦での義村の裏切りを批判した逸話が記されている。
sen.e: In a document "Kokon Cho Monju", it is recorded that when Tanetsuna CHIBA, a young noble from the Shimousa Province, was promoted above Yoshimura, a high ranking commander in the shogun's palace, Yoshimura remarked, "the dogs of Shimousa do not know their place;" to this, Tanetsuna replied, "the dogs of MIURA devour their friends," criticizing Yoshimura's betrayal in the Battle of WADA.

In the document "Kokon Cho Monju", it is recorded that when Tanetsuna CHIBA, a young noble from the Shimousa Province, sat on the upper ranking seat than Kamiza (seat of honor) in the Shogun's place, where Yoshimura sat, and Yoshimura remarked, "the dogs of Shimousa do not know their place;" to this, Tanetsuna replied, "the dogs of MIURA devour their friends," criticizing Yoshimura's betrayal in the Battle of WADA.
sen.cmt: 不適切な不定冠詞aを変更しました。また、着座とあることから、実際に座った位置を指す文意を、地位の意と誤解されているもようです。
sen.e: In the document "Kokon Cho Monju", it is recorded that when Tanetsuna CHIBA, a young noble from the Shimousa Province, sat on the upper ranking seat than Kamiza (seat of honor) in the Shogun's place, where Yoshimura sat, and Yoshimura remarked, "the dogs of Shimousa do not know their place;" to this, Tanetsuna replied, "the dogs of MIURA devour their friends," criticizing Yoshimura's betrayal in the Battle of WADA.
